comments.text:
When Justice Roberts asked the proponents of same-sex marriage if four 
lawyers could marry they replied "that is not what marriage is."  How did 
they come to that conclusion?  What is marriage?
Jesus says in reference to being challenged about divorce, if it was 
legal(?), and the adversary knew it was legal, "From the beginning God made 
them male and female for each other.  Thus a young man shall leave his 
father and mother and cleave to his wife.  And the two shall become one 
flesh.  What God has joined together let not anyone put asunder."  (Mark 
10.7)
Same-sex marriage is going to be the law of the land, no doubt.  But let's 
be consistent.   If you advocate same-sex marriage you are certainly not 
following the definition of marriage that Jesus gives. 
I would ask, as it was brought up in the movie Philadelphia, if sodomy is 
the same moral equivalent as natural sexual intercourse?  Now don't get 
bent out of shape.  But isn't that suggested by saying that same-sex 
marriage is equivalent with traditional marriage?   As Washington said in 
the movie, "Explain it to me like I was a child."  Because that is what we 
will be telling our children in school sex education that one is just as 
acceptable as the other.  Maybe we can even encourage them to try both and 
see which they like the best.﻿

comments.text:
Matthew 19:10-12

Some Christians confidently assert that God did not create homosexual 
people "that way." This is important because they realize if God did create 
gays "that way," rejecting them would be tantamount to rejecting God’s work 
in creation. In pressing their “creation order” argument, some Christians 
are fond of saying, "God made Adam and Eve, not Adam and Steve!" To bolster 
their position, they often cite Jesus’ words in Matthew 19:4-5, where he 
responds to a question about whether divorce is permissible:

“Jesus answered, ‘Have you not read that the One who made them at the 
beginning made them male and female, and said, “For this reason a man shall 
leave his father and mother and be joined to his wife and the two shall 
become one flesh”? Therefore, what God has joined together, let no one 
separate.’ ”

From these words, some Christians draw the conclusion that heterosexuality 
is the creation norm and, thus, heterosexual marriage is the only 
legitimate way for people to form romantic relationships. Ironically, 
Jesus’ own words in this very same passage refute these conclusions.

As the dialogue continues, Jesus’ disciples are disturbed by his strict 
teaching on divorce. The disciples say that if divorce is not a ready 
option, perhaps it would be best for a man not to marry a woman. Jesus 
responds:

“Not everyone can accept this teaching, but only those to whom it is given. 
For there are eunuchs who have been so from birth, and there are eunuchs 
who have been made eunuchs by others, and there are eunuchs who have made 
themselves eunuchs for the sake of the kingdom of heaven. Let anyone accept 
this who can.” (Matthew 19:11-12)

Here Jesus identifies three classes of men who should not marry women. 
Taking his categories in reverse order, first, there are those who have 
made themselves “eunuchs” for the kingdom of heaven, i.e., those who 
foreswear marriage to better serve God. Second, he mentions those who have 
been “made eunuchs by others,” an apparent reference to castrated males. 
But Jesus mentions a third category — eunuchs who were born that way. Some 
might argue that Jesus was referring to males born without testicles, but 
this would be extremely rare. Moreover, this interpretation ignores how the 
term “born eunuchs” was used in other literature of the time.

In the ancient world, including ancient Jewish culture (as reflected in the 
Talmud), “natural” or “born” eunuchs were not associated with missing 
testicles. Rather, they were associated with stereotypically effeminate 
characteristics and behavior (just like modern gay men), and were thought 
by Rabbi Eliezer to be subject to “cure” (just like modern gays). Moreover, 
as we have also seen, eunuchs were commonly associated with homosexual 
desire. (For a complete discussion of the term "born eunuch" and the 
connection with homosexuality, see The Early Church Welcomed a Gay Man.) As 
a reasonably informed person of his time, Jesus would have been aware of 
this common view of eunuchs. Yet he very matter-of-factly asserts that some 
people are simply born that way. The implication of his statement is 
profound — God created gay people the way they are! Jesus says so.

Unlike Rabbi Eliezer, Jesus feels no need to “cure” these born eunuchs. He 
speaks no words of condemnation. Rather he lists people born gay alongside 
another honored class (eunuchs for the kingdom), and accepts them as a 
natural part of God’s creation order.

Thus, when Matthew 19 is read as a whole, we see Jesus teaches that most 
people are created for heterosexual marriage. (We too accept this as God’s 
predominant creation paradigm.) But, unlike some modern Christians, Jesus 
does not see this as the only honorable way to live. He acknowledges that 
some human beings have been created by God to follow a less common, but 
equally legitimate path. There are some who have been eunuchs from birth — 
made that way by God.﻿

comments.author: Ehrin Lloyd

comments.text:
Anderson Cooper in accusing the senator of jumping the gun by voting in 
favor of a "preemptive law" that would ban the acceptance of the gay 
lifestyle in the school curriculum. In view of the position already adopted 
by other States in this matter, would voting a preemptive law banning 
fracking in Arizona be considered just as foolish and ignorant as the big 
fellow says? In my book and that of the senator's, I would submit that 
traditional family values override the push in favor of LGTB agenda (as 
well as fracking).
Too bad the senator didn't have his coffee before facing Anderson Cooper 
whose positions in this matter are very well-known, professionally 
articulated but also often rhetorical; the allusion to divorced and unwed 
mothers being discriminated against by some so-called Catholics is a good 
example of that.﻿
comments.author: Denis Mailloux

comments.text:
Hello Robert:

As for your appeal to my humanity, maybe I should have expanded a little 
more on the first sentence of the last paragraph of my previous retro.
 
This being said, you will convene that reactions of all sorts have to 
be expected each time the views of the LGBT community overflow into the 
public square or political arena. Of course, political safeguards have and 
should be insured to protect minorities against the whims of the majority. 
But does this automatically entail that we invariably have to espouse 
the views of the few because it is supposedly the right thing to do? In 
this regard, as David Letterman would like us to think, we are not talking 
here about the scourge of slavery where the whip, torture and segregation 
were the order of the day. We are talking about a rather new 
phenomenon that encroaches on the deep seated values of family life and 
religion from which this country benefited so much and even bloomed.

I fully realize that those views, all conservative they may sound, might 
not appeal to the more liberal voices. To abdicate them however, even so 
slightly, would only signify that they always were retrograde and thus all 
the more disposable. If you doubt me, ask around you, and do not forget to 
keep me posted.

Peace
comments.author: Denis Mailloux

comments.text:
I have no quarrel with open, honest political debate.  You have every right 
to speak your mind and your heart.  I suppose I had hoped to appeal to your 
sensibilities as a brother in humanity, to see if there was some way I 
could help you see that our struggle goes much deeper than politics.  It is 
intrinsic to my humanity, actually.  I really hope and believe that if good 
people really understood how difficult it is for gender "queer" people to 
live in American society, they would soften their condemnation of us and 
maybe even see that we just want to be treated with respect and accorded 
the same freedoms and responsibilities under the law, nothing more or less. 
 But, if you are not so inclined, I thank you for your attention.  Be happy 
and well.
comments.author: Robert Knight

comments.text:
+Robert Knight

Thank you for your retro. I would be pleased to discuss it but I think you 
have just pointed out the main reason why, as a Catholic, I object to the 
gay lifestyle being propelled at the forefront of the public discourse. 
Yes, It is truly a political agenda aimed at reshaping society to the core, 
with ramifications not only at the family but also at the religious and 
economic levels. LGBT is indeed a political movement. Homosexualism, if we 
could call it so, therefore opens itself to a justified criticism on the 
public place.

Far from me to condemn, shun or even ostracize homosexuals. However, I do 
not see why I should refrain from speaking against what you adequately 
called their political agenda.
comments.author: Denis Mailloux

comments.text:
I liked your comment on my post, so I came to investigate your site.  I was 
hoping to engage you in a discussion about this issue.  Would you be 
willing to discuss with me the position of religion against the LGBT 
political agenda?  I think it would be an interesting conversation between 
us.
